facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 79 to 81 of 1961 were appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1959, of the Kerala High Court in O. P. No. 579, 580 and 647 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 79 to 81 of 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1959, of the Kerala High Court in 0. P. No. 579, 580 and 647 of 1959. U. Isaac, Girish Chandra and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on February 14, 1963 by MUDHOLKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 14. The judgment of the, Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR. J.- The Municipal Council, Palai, the appellant before us, passed a resolution on September 12, 1958 providing for the use from October 1, 1958 of a public bus stand companystructed by it -for stage carriage buses starting from and returning to the municipal limits of Palai or passing through its limits.

facts.text: Municipal Council, Palai passed a resolution on September 12, 1958 providing for the use from October 1, 1958 of a public bus stand constructed by it for stage carriage buses starting from and returning to or passing through Palai municipal limits.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Council, Palai, the appellant before us, passed a resolution on September 12, 1958 providing for the use from October 1, 1958 of a public bus stand companystructed by it -for stage carriage buses starting from and returning to the municipal limits of Palai or passing through its limits. A fee of Re. 1 per day was to be, Charged on every such bus and 50 nP. per day on buses which merely pass through the municipal limits.

facts.text: The resolution of September 12, 1958 imposed a fee of Re. 1 per day on every stage carriage bus using the bus stand and 50 nP. per day on buses merely passing through the municipal limits.

anchor.surface_text: A fee of Re. 1 per day was to be, Charged on every such bus and 50 nP. per day on buses which merely pass through the municipal limits. The resolution also prohibited the use after that date of any other public place or the sides of any public street within Palai municipal limits as a bus stand or a halting place.

facts.text: The resolution of September 12, 1958 prohibited the use after October 1, 1958 of any other public place or sides of public street within Palai municipal limits as a bus stand or halting place.

anchor.surface_text: The resolution also prohibited the use after that date of any other public place or the sides of any public street within Palai municipal limits as a bus stand or a halting place. At the request of the bus operators the Municipal Council, by a resolution dated September 24, 1958 reduced the rates from Re. 1 to 80 np. per day and from 50 nP. to 40 nP. per day.

facts.text: Municipal Council by resolution dated September 24, 1958 reduced the fees from Re. 1 to 80 nP. per day and from 50 nP. to 40 nP. per day at the request of bus operators.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the bus operators the Municipal Council, by a resolution dated September 24, 1958 reduced the rates from Re. 1 to 80 np. per day and from 50 nP. to 40 nP. per day. By a further resolution dated November 22, 1959 the Municipal Council modified the resolution of September 12, 1958 and instead imposed a prohibition on using as a bus stand or halting place a public place or side of a public road within a radius of six furlongs from the Municipal bus stand.

facts.text: Municipal Council by resolution dated November 22, 1959 modified the September 12, 1958 resolution and imposed prohibition on using as bus stand or halting place any public place or side of public road within six furlongs radius from the municipal bus stand.

anchor.surface_text: By a further resolution dated November 22, 1959 the Municipal Council modified the resolution of September 12, 1958 and instead imposed a prohibition on using as a bus stand or halting place a public place or side of a public road within a radius of six furlongs from the Municipal bus stand. Some of the operators who were using that bus stand did number pay the charges due from them for the use of the bus stand.

facts.text: Some bus operators who used the bus stand did not pay the charges due for its use.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the operators who were using that bus stand did number pay the charges due from them for the use of the bus stand. Demand numberices were, therefore, issued against them.

facts.text: Demand notices were issued against bus operators including respondents Joseph, Anthony and Eapen for unpaid charges.

anchor.surface_text: Demand numberices were, therefore, issued against them. The respondent in this appeal, Joseph, as well as the respondents in the other two appeals, Anthony and Eapen, who were recipients of such numberices preferred writ petitions before the High Court of Kerala challenging the validity of the action taken by the Municipal Council and praying for quashing of the demand numberices issued against them.

facts.text: Respondents Joseph, Anthony and Eapen preferred writ petitions before Kerala High Court challenging validity of Municipal Council's actions and praying for quashing of demand notices.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in this appeal, Joseph, as well as the respondents in the other two appeals, Anthony and Eapen, who were recipients of such numberices preferred writ petitions before the High Court of Kerala challenging the validity of the action taken by the Municipal Council and praying for quashing of the demand numberices issued against them. it may be mentioned that the various resolutions of the Municipal Council to which we have adverted were passed by it in exercise of the powers companyferred upon it by ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act, XXIII of 1116 M. E.  which companyresponds to A. D. 1941 .

facts.text: Municipal Council resolutions were passed in exercise of powers conferred by sections 286 and 287 of Travancore District Municipalities Act XXIII of 1116 M.E. (corresponding to 1941 A.D.).

anchor.surface_text: it may be mentioned that the various resolutions of the Municipal Council to which we have adverted were passed by it in exercise of the powers companyferred upon it by ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act, XXIII of 1116 M. E.  which companyresponds to A. D. 1941 . Those provisions read thus 286  1  The Municipal Council may companystruct or provide public landing places, halting places and cart-stands and may levy fees for the use of the same.

facts.text: About 80 stage carriage buses start, halt in, or pass through Palai municipal limits.

anchor.surface_text: The reason given by the Municipal Council for taking action tinder these provisions is that about 80 stage carriage buses start, halt in, or pass through the municipal limits of Palai and the members of the public using them were being put to serious inconveniences for want of a proper waiting room and other necessary companyveniences.

facts.text: Municipal Council utilised a plot of land worth Rs. 50,000 at the centre of the town and constructed a bus stand at a cost of Rs. 80,000 providing waiting rooms, sitting accommodation, fans, sanitary conveniences, drinking water, garages and booking offices free for users.

anchor.surface_text: In order to improve matters the Municipal Council claims to have utilised a plot of land worth Rs. 50,000 located almost at the centre of the town and companystructed a bus stand at a companyt Rs. 80,000 wherein, among other things, it has provided separate waiting rooms for men and women, sitting accommodation, electric fans, sanitary companyveniences, drinking water etc., as also garages and booking offices free of companyt for bus operators using the bus stand.

facts.text: Respondents contended that ss. 286 and 287 of Travancore District Municipalities Act were repealed by implication by s. 72 of Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act, 1125 M.E. (1950) which came into force on January 5, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was companytended that the provisions of ss. 26 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act stood repealed by implication by virtue of the provisions of s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act, 1125 M. E.  companyresponding to A. D. 1950  which came into force on January 5, 1950.

facts.text: Kerala High Court accepted respondents' contention that ss. 286 and 287 were repealed by implication by s. 72 of T.C. Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the companytention urged by the respondents in these three appeals and observed The T.C. Motor Vehicles Act, 1125 was enacted, as the preamble shows, in order to provide a uniform law relating to motor vehicles and we see numberreason why sections like 286 and 287 to the extent they militate against such uniformity should number be companysidered as having been repealed by implication

facts.text: Supreme Court held there is no implied repeal of ss. 286 and 287 by s. 72 of Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: Where such is the position, we cannot imply repeal. The result of this undoubtedly would be that a provision which is added subsequently, that is, which represents the latest will of the legislature will have an overriding effect on the earlier provision

facts.text: No action has been taken under section 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act by the Government so far.

anchor.surface_text: No action under section 72 has so far been taken by the Government and, therefore, the resolutions of the municipal Council still hold good.

facts.text: Respondent did not appear in the Supreme Court appeals.

anchor.surface_text: U. Isaac, Girish Chandra and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant. The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Public using buses in Palai were put to serious inconveniences due to lack of proper waiting room and conveniences, and unsystematic parking affected sanitation.

anchor.surface_text: and the members of the public using them were being put to serious inconveniences for want of a proper waiting room and other necessary companyveniences. Further, the unsystematic manner in which the buses were parked and plied affected the sanitation of the town.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act was partially replaced by Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 (Central Act 4 of 1939) on extension to Travancore-Cochin by Part B States Laws Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally we may mention that this section companytinued in force until the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act was replaced partially by the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Central Act 4 of 1939  on its extension to Travancore Cochin by Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951  Central Act 3 of 1951 .

facts.text: Kerala High Court quashed the demand notices issued by Municipal Council.

ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act, XXIII of 1116 M. E.  which corresponds to A. D. 1941 . Those provisions read thus 286  1  The Municipal Council may construct or provide public landing places, halting places and cart-stands and may levy fees for the use of the same.

arguments.claim: Provisions of ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act stood repealed by implication by s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was contended that the provisions of ss. 26 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act stood repealed by implication by virtue of the provisions of s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act, 1125 M. E.  corresponding to A. D. 1950  which came into force on January 5, 1950.

arguments.court_reasoning: No positive repugnancy, no direct conflict, not exhaustive code, different fields; harmonious construction possible

arguments.claim: Municipal Council acted within powers conferred by ss. 286 and 287 and in public interest for health and sanitation

anchor.surface_text: It is claimed on behalf of the Municipal Council that by establishing the bus stand it has not only acted within the scope of the powers conferred by the Act but also in public interest and for preserving the health and sanitation of the town.

arguments.court_reasoning: Powers under ss. 286-287 valid, no repeal

arguments.claim: TC Motor Vehicles Act enacted for uniform law relating to motor vehicles; ss. 286-287 militate against uniformity and repealed by implication

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the contention urged by the respondents in these three appeals and observed The T.C. Motor Vehicles Act, 1125 was enacted, as the preamble shows, in order to provide a uniform law relating to motor vehicles and we see no reason why sections like 286 and 287 to the extent they militate against such uniformity should not be considered as having been repealed by implication

arguments.court_reasoning: Uniformity argument insufficient for implied repeal without repugnancy

arguments.claim: Later conferred power overrides prior Act where same power given to different bodies (citing Daw v. Metropolitan Board of Works)

arguments.claim: There is a presumption against implied repeal unless positive repugnancy

anchor.surface_text: It is undoubtedly true that the legislature can exercise the power of repeal by implication. But it is an equally well- settled principle of law that there is a presumption against an implied repeal.

arguments.claim: No implied repeal absent positive repugnancy making provisions irreconcilable (citing Crawford, Crosby v. Patch, Sedgwick)

anchor.surface_text: As has been observed by Crawford on Statutory Construction, p. 631, para 311 There must be what is often called such a positive repugnancy between the two provisions of the old and the new statutes that they cannot be reconciled and made to stand together.

arguments.claim: To find repugnancy: (1) direct conflict? (2) exhaustive code? (3) same field? (citing Deep Chand v. State of UP)
General law does not repeal special/local statute absent irreconcilable conflict (citing Sutherland on Statutory Construction)
arguments.court_reasoning: s.72 general/wider, ss.286-287 special/local to municipalities

arguments.claim: No direct inconsistency between s.72 (Govt power to determine places) and s.286 (Municipal power to provide/levy fees)
s.72 to be read in continuity with ss.286-287, both enabling provisions can coexist
No conflict until actual exercise of power under s.72 overrides municipal action
arguments.court_reasoning: No action under s.72 yet, resolutions hold good; but s.72 can override if exercised

arguments.claim: Repugnancy must exist in fact, not mere possibility (citing Shyamakant Lal and AG Ontario)
arguments.court_reasoning: Canadian case distinguishable as provision not in force

holdings.text: ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act have not been repealed by implication by s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act

anchor.surface_text: Where such is the position, we cannot imply repeal. The result of this undoubtedly would be that a provision which is added subsequently, that is, which represents the latest will of the legislature will have an overriding effect on the earlier provision

holdings.reasoning_summary: No positive repugnancy as per presumption against repeal; Deep Chand tests applied (no direct conflict, not exhaustive code, different fields); harmonious construction; general vs special statute rule

holdings.text: There is no direct conflict between ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act and s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Municipal Council can provide halting places and levy fees under s.286 while Government can determine places under s.72 simultaneously without conflict; consultation obviates issues

holdings.text: s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act does not constitute an exhaustive code replacing ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Deep Chand test; s.72 enabling provision for wider areas including non-municipal, not replacing municipal powers

holdings.text: ss. 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act (special/local) are not repealed by the general provision in s. 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sutherland on Statutory Construction: general law does not repeal special/local absent irreconcilable conflict; s.72 wider but ss.286-287 confined to municipalities

holdings.text: The proper construction is to regard s. 72 as in continuity with ss. 286 and 287 allowing both provisions to coexist
holdings.reasoning_summary: Both enabling provisions; no intent to replace; can coexist with s.72 overriding only if exercised post-consultation

holdings.text: The resolutions of the Municipal Council under ss. 286 and 287 still hold good as no action has been taken under s. 72

anchor.surface_text: No action under section 72 has so far been taken by the Government and, therefore, the resolutions of the municipal Council still hold good.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conflict arises until s.72 exercised; repugnancy must exist in fact, not possibility; municipal actions valid
